Cen./Decen.: centralized/decentralized FL models;The symbols “+, ++, +++” indicate low, moderate, and high capability, respectively;I𝐼I: the number of nodes, J𝐽J: the number of iterations, ΓΓ\Gamma: the number of aggregated durations;The tick “✓” indicates a functionality supported, whereas the cross “✗” indicates not supported;The learning efficiency is defined as the ratio of the learning time to the total time;Syn./Asyn.: synchronous/asynchronous communication modes.
references: This paper develops a decentralized FL model with asynchronous parameter sharing to address the abovementioned issues. In particular, the proposed model has multi-branch architectures and allows various learning parameters at each node, forming a sum of multi-branch non-convex functions. By recalling the Shapley-Folkman lemma [11], a sum of multi-branch non-convex functions can approach a convex function when the number of branches becomes large. Thus, the decentralized FL model is less non-convex, and its learning process converges to a global stationary point with a higher probability than the centralized FL model. In addition, when the dataset is uniformly deployed over each node, and the size of the dataset becomes large, the learning performance and convergence rate of training algorithms improve with the number of distributed nodes increases.111In principle, the assumption requires that the data distribution at each node is identical to the distribution of the total dataset [12], which is unfortunately hard to satisfy in real-world applications. To address this issue, the cross-gradient aggregation (CGA) algorithm is widely used in simulation experiments to approach the distribution of the total dataset [3]. On the one hand, the asynchronous parameter-sharing mechanism makes the learning and parameter transmission occur in parallel. Thus, a high learning efficiency can be obtained compared with a synchronous architecture. On the other hand, designing a decentralized FL model at the distributed nodes requires an efficient communication network that balances learning performance maximization and transmission delay minimization. In this regard, the asynchronous parameter-sharing method is adopted among distributed nodes. Accordingly, we derive a convergence bound incorporating transmission delay and learning performance. In light of the convergence bound and aggregated duration, we also develop algorithms regarding node scheduling and bandwidth allocation to minimize the transmission delay while maximizing the learning performance. In brevity, Table I compares the state-of-the-art and proposed schemes.

Notation:
Scalars and vectors are denoted by italic regular letters and lower-case ones in bold typeface, respectively. Both space and sets are denoted by calligraphic letters and can be easily identified in the context. The symbol 𝟎0\bm{0} indicates a column vector with all-zero elements. The operation |𝒳|𝒳\left|\mathcal{X}\right| denotes the cardinality of the set 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X}, and 𝒴∖𝒳𝒴𝒳\mathcal{Y}\setminus\mathcal{X} denotes the complement of set 𝒴𝒴\mathcal{Y} except 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X}. The arithmetic operations 𝒙⪰𝒚succeeds-or-equals𝒙𝒚\bm{x}\succeq\bm{y} denotes that each element of 𝒙𝒙\bm{x} is greater than or equal to the counterpart of 𝒚𝒚\bm{y}. The Landau notation 𝒪​(⋅)𝒪⋅\mathcal{O}(\cdot) denotes the order of arithmetic operations. The notation U​(x0,x1)𝑈subscript𝑥0subscript𝑥1U(x_{0},\,x_{1}) denotes a random variable uniformly distributed over the interval [x0,x1]subscript𝑥0subscript𝑥1\left[x_{0},\,x_{1}\right], x0≤x1subscript𝑥0subscript𝑥1x_{0}\leq x_{1}. Moreover, the ceiling operator is defined as ⌈x⌉≜min⁡{n∈ℤ:n≥x}≜𝑥:𝑛ℤ𝑛𝑥\left\lceil x\right\rceil\triangleq\min\{n\in\mathbb{Z}:n\geq x\}, where ℤℤ\mathbb{Z} is the set of integers. The operator [⋅]+superscriptdelimited-[]⋅\left[\cdot\right]^{+} denotes the orthogonal projection of 𝒘isubscript𝒘𝑖\bm{w}_{i}. The functions sup(⋅)supremum⋅\sup(\cdot) and inf(⋅)infimum⋅\inf(\cdot) take a supermum and an infimum, respectively. Finally, we define a binary indicator function 𝕀​(x)=1𝕀𝑥1\mathbb{I}(x)=1 if the condition x𝑥x is true and 𝕀​(x)=0𝕀𝑥0\mathbb{I}(x)=0, otherwise. The main symbols used throughout the paper are defined in Table II for ease of reference.

references: This subsection illustrates the effectiveness of node scheduling and bandwidth allocation. In the pertaining simulation experiments, we adopt similar wireless parameters as those reported in [27], and their default values are summarized in Table III unless specified otherwise. Apart from the conventional centralized FL averaging model (FedAv for short) [1] and Algorithm 1 with optimal resource allocation (Alg. 111 for short), we also consider two other benchmark ones: the distributed FL algorithms with uniform bandwidth allocation (Distributed+Uniform for short) or random bandwidth allocation (Distributed+Random for short).
